verses.text: A few days later, when Jesus returned to Capernaum, the news spread that He was at home.
verses.comment: Jesus centers His ministry in Capernaum, indicating the importance of a physical home for gathering the faithful, a theme that echoes the establishment of spiritual community.

verses.text: So many people gathered that there was no longer room, not even at the door, and He spoke the word to them.
verses.comment: Jesus' preaching draws crowds beyond capacity, highlighting the magnetic power of His teaching and the human need for divine truth.

verses.text: Then men came to Him, carrying a paralyzed man, borne by four.
verses.comment: Their cooperation shows the importance of communal faith, and mutual support in seeking healing and grace.

verses.text: And when they could not get near Him because of the crowd, they made an opening in the roof above Him, and after breaking through, they lowered the mat with the paralyzed man lying on it.
verses.comment: The determination to reach Jesus demonstrates strong faith and persistence, which are vital for receiving the Lord’s healing.

verses.text: When Jesus saw their faith, He said to the paralytic, 'Son, your sins are forgiven.'
verses.comment: Jesus responds first to the man’s spiritual need by granting forgiveness—pointing to the authority of Christ to forgive sin and the priority of spiritual healing (see Ps. 32:1-5).

verses.text: But some of the scribes were sitting there, reasoning in their hearts:
verses.comment: The scribes' inner questioning illustrates skepticism toward divine authority exercised among men; their hearts reveal a challenge to Jesus' divine prerogative.

verses.text: 'Why does this man speak like that? He’s blaspheming! Who can forgive sins but God alone?'
verses.comment: Forgiving sins is God's exclusive prerogative (see Isa. 43:25), so Jesus’ claim implies divine authority, affirming His identity for those with spiritual insight.

verses.text: Immediately, Jesus, knowing in His spirit what they were thinking within themselves, said to them, 'Why are you reasoning about these things in your hearts?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ ability to know their hidden thoughts points to His divine omniscience.

verses.text: 'Which is easier, to say to the paralytic, “Your sins are forgiven,” or to say, “Rise, take up your mat and walk”?'
verses.comment: Jesus appeals to the visible miracle to confirm the invisible spiritual authority over sin—a union of the material and spiritual, which foreshadows the sacramental nature of grace.

verses.text: 'But so that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins'—He said to the paralytic—
verses.comment: The title 'Son of Man' hearkens to Daniel 7:13—a Messianic, divine figure given authority. Jesus’ authority to forgive sin confirms His active role as redeemer.

verses.text: 'I say to you, rise, take up your mat, and go home.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ word has power both to heal and to forgive, revealing both spiritual and physical dimensions of salvation.

verses.text: And he got up, immediately picked up his mat, and went out before them all, so that everyone was amazed and praised God, saying, 'We have never seen anything like this.'
verses.comment: A public miracle inspires awe and glorifies God, echoing Old Testament patterns of confirmation through signs (see Luke 7:16).

verses.text: He went out again beside the sea, and the whole crowd came to Him, and He taught them.
verses.comment: Teaching at the shore is a recurring image in the Gospels, symbolizing Jesus as the source of living water to all who gather.

verses.text: As He was passing by, He saw Levi the son of Alphaeus sitting at the tax booth. He said to him, 'Follow Me.' And Levi rose and followed Him.
verses.comment: The call of Levi highlights Jesus’ initiative to invite sinners into discipleship, demonstrating mercy and election not based on merit but on grace.

verses.text: While Jesus was dining at Levi’s house, many tax collectors and sinners sat down with Jesus and His disciples, for many were following Him.
verses.comment: Table fellowship with sinners emphasizes radical inclusion and a community formed around the person of Christ.

verses.text: When the scribes and Pharisees saw Him eating with sinners and tax collectors, they said to His disciples, 'Why does He eat with tax collectors and sinners?'
verses.comment: Their questioning exposes the depth of Jesus’ mission to all people, and it serves to illustrate the importance of a healing community.

verses.text: When Jesus heard this, He said to them, 'Those who are well have no need of a physician, but those who are sick. I did not come to call the righteous, but sinners.'
verses.comment: Christ’s mission is to heal sin, emphasizing universal need and the spiritual physician’s role as savior. This links to the necessity of ongoing repentance (Ps. 51:5).

verses.text: Now John’s disciples and the Pharisees were fasting. And people came and asked Him, 'Why do John’s disciples and the disciples of the Pharisees fast, but Your disciples do not fast?'
verses.comment: The question about fasting centers on spiritual discipline and tradition; Jesus' answer will position Himself as the focus of true devotion.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'Can the wedding guests fast while the bridegroom is with them? As long as they have the bridegroom with them, they cannot fast.'
verses.comment: Jesus identifies Himself as the bridegroom—a direct Messianic metaphor—with implications of covenant and celebration, prefiguring the relationship between Christ and the Church.

verses.text: 'But the days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them, and then they will fast in those days.'
verses.comment: Jesus foreshadows His coming death, after which fasting and spiritual discipline resume, pointing to periods of mourning and anticipation in Christian practice.

verses.text: 'No one sews a patch of unshrunk cloth onto an old garment. If he does, the new pulls away from the old, and a worse tear is made.'
verses.comment: The parable indicates the incompatibility of old and new covenants, showing the need for a fundamentally renewed relationship with God.

verses.text: 'And no one puts new wine into old wineskins. If he does, the wine will burst the skins, and both the wine and the skins are lost. But new wine must be put into fresh wineskins.'
verses.comment: This image stresses the complete renewal brought by Christ; Christianity isn’t just a reform of Judaism but a new reality requiring new forms and practices.

verses.text: One Sabbath, as He was passing through the grainfields, His disciples began to pluck heads of grain as they walked along.
verses.comment: The disciples’ actions are permitted by the Law for travelers (see Deut. 23:25), but the Sabbath becomes a test of authority.

verses.text: The Pharisees said to Him, 'Look, why are they doing what is not lawful on the Sabbath?'
verses.comment: The Pharisees accuse the disciples of breaking the Sabbath, but this sets up Jesus’ teaching on the true purpose of the Law.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Have you never read what David did, when he was in need and hungry, he and those with him?'
verses.comment: Jesus uses Scripture to show that necessity can supersede ritual, foreshadowing a greater interpretation of the Law rooted in mercy.

verses.text: 'How he entered the house of God, in the days of Abiathar the high priest, and ate the bread of the Presence, which only the priests are allowed to eat, and he also gave some to those with him?'
verses.comment: David’s action prefigures the principle that mercy and human need stand above ritual; it also hints at the sanctity and reality of the bread in God’s house as a source of life.

verses.text: And He said to them, 'The Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms that the Sabbath’s purpose is for the benefit of people—a principle of divine compassion operating through observance and tradition.

verses.text: So the Son of Man is Lord even of the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Jesus openly declares His divinity by claiming lordship over the Sabbath, which is instituted by God Himself; this directly links Him to the divine Messiah prophesied in Daniel.
